title: Will the Centers for Disease Control elevate their travel guidance for Brazil to Warning Level 3 due to the Zika virus before the Olympics begin?
preds: political non-starter especially considering current U.S. Florida cases
The probability is now surely less than 0.5.

CNN, August 1, 'CDC issues historic travel warning over Miami Zika outbreak': http://www.cnn.com/2016/08/01/health/cdc-miami-florida-zika-travel-warning/
Clip from article:
"The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention issued an unprecedented travel warning Monday, advising pregnant women and their partners not to travel to a small community just north of downtown Miami, where Zika is actively circulating. This is the first time the CDC has warned people not to travel to an American neighborhood for fear of catching an infectious disease, according to agency spokesman Tom Skinner."

CDC page for travelers going to Olympics in Brazil

The Globe and Mail, July 21, '‘Very bad news for Brazil’: Zika virus found in second mosquito species': http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/zika-virus-found-in-second-mosquito-species-is-very-bad-news-for-brazil/article31070755/
Clips from GM article:
"Research by Brazil’s top public-health institute, the Oswaldo Cruz Foundation (Fiocruz), has found the Zika virus in a mosquito species called Culex quinquefasciatus – far more common than the species that government had said was the vector for the virus.
The findings, as yet unpublished, suggest Brazil may need to change its Zika response strategy, and it is grim news for a country in the grip of a mysterious epidemic, just two weeks before tens of thousands of visitors arrive for the Olympics.
Zika was found in Culex quinquefasciatus in the northeastern city of Recife, ground zero for the outbreak of fetal brain defects caused by the virus – and this species is 20 times more common there than Aedes aegypti, which until now has been identified as the main vector.
“It’s very bad news for Brazil,” said Constancia Ayres, the entomologist who conducted the research and who has been a lonely voice insisting that it was risky to focus exclusively on Aedes aegypti as Brazil scrambled to respond to the Zika outbreak over the last year. “We have a national program for controlling Aedes – but we have nothing for Culex – so if Culex is an important vector then we have to start from zero.”
The warning level has not been raised yet and there has been no recent new outbreaks/increases to indicate a compelling reason to raise it in the time left.
I am forecasting based on the general news reports and GJP consensus with just 3 weeks to go.

NPR, July 14, 'Zika Epidemic May Have Peaked But Will Threaten U.S. For Years': http://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2016/07/14/486047678/zika-epidemic-may-have-peaked-but-will-threaten-u-s-for-years
NYT, July 15, 'First Case of Female-to-Male Transmission of Zika Is Recorded': http://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/16/nyregion/zika-virus-female-to-male-sexual-transmission.html
Clips from NYT article:
"The evidence of a previously undocumented means of transmission is the latest twist in a viral outbreak that continues to baffle and surprise the world’s leading experts. It is forcing officials to rethink, once again, the guidance for health care providers and the general public on how to limit the danger of infection, as the pool of those who could be at risk widens.
Much about how the virus works is a mystery, and it remains challenging to detect; 80 percent of those infected show no symptoms. For those who do get sick, the illness is often mild, and there is no treatment.
But Zika can pose a dire risk to pregnant women. It targets developing nerve cells in fetuses and can lead to a birth defect called microcephaly, in which babies are born with abnormally small heads and brain damage. It may also cause developmental problems after birth.
Down to zero, relying on my overall average as a hedge. However, the CDC is almost certainly not going to elevate its guidance.
Assuming level 3 will be triggered only fir imminent loss of life.
I am forecasting based on the general news reports and GJP consensus.

Zika racket. In a surprise move, Spalding and Wilson sporting goods equipment companies are completing rush orders for half a million Zika rackets. In an astonishing bio-engineering breakthrough the genetic code for the Zika bearing mosquito has been crossed with the fruit bat and the entire country of Brazil has been sprayed with an adjuvant catalyst. "Mosquitoes f**k with the human genome, we are striking back!" an unidentified spokesman (who sounded a lot like Arnold S.) said when reporters sought to confirm this story. In addition, billions of male mosquitoes carrying this genetic code have been released over Rio. Given the short life cycle of the mosquito, by the time the Olympics open, this operation should be complete.
Why Zika rackets? While one might ignore a tiny mosquito bite, no one is going to ignore a fruit bat sized insect sucking blood out of their ankles or necks. The Zika rackets are just a handy way to swat them away and with this breakthrough, there will be no further need for CDC or WHO updates to the warning system.
"Trans-species experiments like this will soon be commonplace", the spokesman concluded. A side benefit is that everyone "will not need screens or mosquito netting. Small gauge chicken wire is sufficient to keep the fruit-bat-sized-Zika-mosquito's out of bedrooms and hotel rooms. With this breakthrough, we expect to see Brazil move up from third world status."
Officials in Texas are considering installing anti-Zika-bat-mosquito artillery along their southern border. "This simplifies everything!" director of Homeland Security officials confirmed, off the record, because they were not authorized to discuss this top secret bio-technology  roll-out before the official press release Monday.

“I am seeing an optimism which is a little exaggerated,” said Jesse Alves, an infectious diseases specialist at the government-run Emilio Ribas hospital in Sao ­Paulo.'

Forbes (opinion), June 20, 'The Zika Virus Poses A Threat To Everyone, Especially At The Rio Olympics': http://www.forbes.com/sites/stevensalzberg/2016/06/20/the-zika-virus-poses-a-threat-to-everyone-especially-at-the-rio-olympics/#1a2b32d4c7ca
Clips from article:
"In response to this threat, a group of more than 200 doctors from around the world has signed an open letter to the WHO (read it here) that
call[s] for the Rio 2016 Games to be postponed and/or moved to another location—but not cancelled—in the name of public health.
The letter points out that Rio is at the epicenter of the Zika epidemic, with 32,000 cases so far, and the holding the games there–with all the associated travel involved–may accelerate the spread of the dangerous Brazilian strain.
The newly emerging risk of Guillain-Barré syndrome makes it clear that Zika virus presents a threat to everyone. The Rio Olympics are likely to make it worse. Anyone planning to visit Rio for the Games should take all the precautions they can, but the best plan might be simply to stay home."

Reuters, May 4, 'Bacteria blocks mosquitoes from transmitting Zika: Brazilian study': http://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-zika-wolbachia-idUSKCN0XV2UU
Clips from article:
"Infecting mosquitoes with a strain of bacteria known as Wolbachia significantly reduced their ability to transmit the Zika virus, Brazilian researchers said on Wednesday, raising hope for this biological method of blocking transmission of the deadly virus.
The bacteria has been released in several countries including Australia, Brazil, Indonesia and Vietnam as part of strategies to control dengue, and the new finding shows the method also works with Zika, a close relative of dengue."

Homeland Security, April 15, 'Zika Virus Map Shows a United States Outbreak is Up Next': http://inhomelandsecurity.com/zika-virus-map-shows-america-next/?utm_source=IHS
Clips from article:
"Earlier this week, the Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) finally unequivocally confirmed that the Zika virus causes microcephaly in infants – confirming what most scientists had long known. However, the story doesn’t end there because – in a new development – the Zika virus is also now known to cause autoimmune diseases in adults too. There is also alarming evidence that the virus can cause the deadly brain ailments meningitis and encephalitis in people of all ages.
The CDC is also on record for stating that the number of disease-carrying mosquitoes (named Aedes aegypt) is much higher than previous estimates. But, health officials have confirmed that the virus doesn’t need the nasty little insect to spread; it’s also a sexually-transmitted disease with the first confirmed case of male-to-male sexual transmittal announced Friday in Texas; a man recently returned from a trip became sick with classic Zika virus symptoms and infected his partner of 10 years who soon came down with the same symptoms. Blood tests confirmed that both men had the Zika virus."

The difference between Zika and Malaria is that Zika has (a yet unproven correlation) with Microcephaly. Pregnant women have a higher risk if there is it is found that Zika is causing Microcephaly. Nearly 70 years have passed since the first isolation of the Zika virus. Once confined to a narrow equatorial belt across Africa and into Asia, the Zika virus is now present everywhere that the right mosquito vectors circulate. One is the tiger mosquito, A albopictus; this rapidly expanding Aedes species lives in close contact with humans and feeds not only at dusk and dawn but also in the daytime—a fact that underscores its dangerous character. In a world marked by globalization and trends of urbanization—which imply a potential source of human-caused perturbations in ecologic balance, and a constant increase in international air travel—Zika virus appears to have a large capacity to spread (like dengue and chikungunya viruses) and colonize new environments. Thus, these three arboviruses, unfortunately have the potential to cause major epidemics at the local, regional, and even global level.  
--------- The above according to a history of Zika by Medscape.

@dob Levels 1, 2, and 3 seems to be recent terminology, I think this started on April 5, 2013 but could not find any news or press releases around that time to confirm.  Older terms seem to include "travel advisory" (recommended against travel to an area unless essential) and "travel health warning" (recommends against nonessential travel to an area because a disease of public health concern is expanding outside of areas or populations that were initially affected. The purpose of a travel warning is to reduce the volume of traffic to affected areas, limiting the risk of spreading the disease to unaffected areas).

This is tricky as we may reach level 3 towards the end of the wet season (May) but would drop back to 2 or 1 in the dry season after. So games are unaffected, but the answer would be a yes. As of now, seems unlikely as efforts to prevent it are on a sharp rise.
Can anyone find the history of the CDC issuing level 3 warnings? It seems like the last was the Ebola outbreak, but it's hard to find previous instances.
I addressed the issue from this angle:

A level 3 warning basically says don't travel to this area unless absolutely necessary. This would be a recommendation to all travelers. From what I have read of Zika virus, the impact on the general public is quite minor, including headache, rash, body aches etc. Zika seems to only cause major problems in pregnant women. The CDC may advise pregnant women or their partners not travel to Brazil because of Zika, I highly doubt they would apply this recommendation to all travelers.

Actual probability somewhat lower, just uncomfortable going super low to start. 
- Zika is widespread, has been known for decades though it's relatively new to the Americas, and usually results in relatively mild illness

The CDC definitions of level 2 emphasizes risk to certain parts of the population vs level 3 risk to all travelers. The risk seems confined to pregnant women and others considering conceiving. I imagine CDC would also be extra prudent before assigning level 3 with Rio 2016.
Olympic economics will reduce chances for an increase in threat level from 2 to 3.

Red or Warning Level 3 means "avoid non-essential travel" link http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/notices   Currently, there are none.  Because Colombia has a large number of Zika cases (5000) but no reported cases of microcephaly. Link http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/notices
Lowering 10% to be just above the consensus.

The same type of mosquito is responsible for transmitting dengue fever, which is by all accounts a more severe and widespread illness. Many scientific studies must be under way right now to find out more, but at present it seems CDC has it just right by highlighting the risk to pregnant women and otherwise generally recommending precautions. If every visitor follows a strict regimen of applying mosquito repellent, not exposing too much skin especially around sunset etc, the risk will be very low.

Zika isn't actively a deadly disease, and can be prevented with existing/relatively easy measures. Putting into practice level 3 precautions would indicate some change in the nature of the virus or some similarly drastic event.

With an aim of lowering further. The warning is already at Level 2 for all and for pregnant it is already effectively level 3 ("CDC recommends that all pregnant women consider postponing travel to areas where Zika virus transmission is ongoing"): http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/volumes/65/wr/mm6502e1.htm
In assessing the literature that is out there at this point, it would appear that a continuation of the level 2 protocol would be sufficient. Thus, my standard non-zero opening.

Zika spreading fast in enough countries that issuing level 3 warnings may not make sense, as it did with Ebola, at least not until the full extent and level of impact of affected zones is known and institutional cooperation agreements established with countries and regions to combat it effectively.
Initial forecast. Want to be somewhat lower than the consensus for now. Good comments, especially interesting @wrichars Seems like two levels:

Level 2 - Increased risk in defined settings or associated with specific risk factors; certain high-risk populations may wish to delay travel to these destinations. So, with LEvel 2, many groups will be cautioned of the risks.

Ebola rated a level 3 -- is Zika equivalent?

Known cases of Zika virus cover so many countries that the CDC would create a huge problem if the went to level 3 everywhere. If they just went to level 3 for Brazil it would be seen as very political. In theory the biggest risks (to pregnant women) can be avoided by not being pregnant. 
If some other issue is discovered about the virus e.g. that the long term affects of having had the virus persist, then its possible that level 3 could be reached.
At the moment level 2 (Increased risk in defined settings or associated with specific risk factors; certain high-risk populations may wish to delay travel to these destinations) seems about right.
